RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the agents: Jorge Luis Trevino and IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR.

Defendant in the case who had his vehicle stopped by a United States Border Patrol agent and is a United States citizen, challenges the stop of his white sedan
Defendant stopped by Officer Reyes, driver of the black truck, exhibited nervous behavior during the stop, claimed the vehicle belonged to his aunt and then his cousin, transported to a checkpoint for further questioning, contends that Officer Reyes exceeded the scope of a traffic stop, subject to an 'unlawful arrest' without probable cause
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.RICARDO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and IGNACIO RODRI: Defendants indicted for transporting undocumented aliens within the United States, stopped near the Mexico border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jorge Luis Trevino: United States Border Patrol Agent with nearly seven years of experience, stationed at the Freer checkpoint for a year and a half, familiar with ninety to ninety-five percent of the vehicles passing down FM 2050, pursued the defendants and conducted registration checks, explained his suspicions and actions during a traffic stop, made observations of passengers' behavior
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Rodriguez: United States Border Patrol Agent who alerted to two suspicious vehicles and is involved in the case
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Agent Rodriguez: United States Border Patrol Agent who alerted to the two vehicles, likely referring to Rodriguez
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Agent Trevino: United States Border Patrol Agent who encountered Defendants' vehicles within fifty miles of the Mexico border, pursued the defendants and conducted registration checks, explained his suspicions and actions during a traffic stop, testified about observations of passengers
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jorge Luis Trevino and Rodriguez: Border Patrol agents involved in the investigation of suspicious vehicles on FM 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mills Bennett: Involved in the case, mentioned during the cross examination of Agent Trevino
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Reymundo Reyes: Officer who conducted a traffic stop of Ignacio Rodriguez, issued a citation, informed him that the vehicle could not continue to its destination, present when Agent Benavides arrived at the scene
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. and Jorge Luis Tr: Individuals involved in the case, with Ignacio Rodriguez as a defendant and Jorge Luis Trevino as a United States Border Patrol Agent
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hugo Benavides: United States Border Patrol Agent who arrived at the scene of the traffic stop, presented himself, inquired into Defendant's citizenship and travel plans, awaited the results of the canine search, transported Ignacio Rodriguez to the checkpoint for further questioning
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mr. Rodriguez: Defendant stopped by Officer Reyes, driver of the vehicle, transported to a checkpoint for further questioning
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Agent Benavides: United States Border Patrol Agent who conducted questioning and transported Ignacio Rodriguez to a checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Marco Montemayor: Special Agent for the United States Department of Homeland Security involved in investigating an attempted alien smuggling event, interviewed Ignacio Rodriguez around 11:30 p.m. after he was transported to the checkpoint
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Marco Montemayor and his partner: Agents who interviewed Ignacio Rodriguez after he waived his Miranda rights
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ricardo Rodriguez: Defendant stopped near the Mexico border, driver of a white sedan
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Ignacio Rodriguez: Defendant stopped near the Mexico border, driver of a black truck
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Jorge Luis Trevino and IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ: Border Patrol agents involved in the investigation of suspicious vehicles on FM 2050
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Hugo Benavides in CHUNK_TEXT: United States Border Patrol Agent who questioned Defendant at the Border Patrol station
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.IGNACIO RODRIGUEZ, JR. in CHUNK_TEXT: Defendant whose involuntary transportation to the Border Patrol station for questioning was deemed 'sufficiently like an arrest' and required probable cause
